Entry.1: Ma'adiEgypt. am starting new year as well as possible
Entry.2:
Sunday 2nd
church Parade. usual Routine Rumour Ripe concerning our departure from here shortly
Entry.4: the last three day it has been raining in Egypt. Ma'adi
Entry.6:
PrivateA.C. Truman
McIntyre St Inverell

Thursday 6

No 1526

A.C. Truman
D of A
Entry.8:
Miss Nancey Truman
McIntyre St
Inverell

JANUARY,1916
Entry.9:
X
met G Gray G R Gray 2927..
Entry.13:
on Sarapeum

the place itself is situated about 1 ½ miles from the Suez canal it is and sand also subject to dust storms and hot winds which are very uncomfortable. we go swimmingthe canal 2 a week and I assure it varies the monotony when I came through the canal at June last 1915 there were trenches on both sides of the canal but at present they have them 12 miles back the canal areoplanes are constant visitors belonging of courseto the allies war boats are still stationed in the canal. if the turks happen to attack the canal everything is ready for a hearty welcome.

S McCarthy

Ismalia is the nearest town
Entry.17:
Sarapeum is situated 11 miles from Ismalia and 49 miles from Suez there is no town here only a Railway Station and a small population of natives. there is a fresh water canal where we water our horses about ½ mile from our camp the water is not fit for human consumption but still the natives drink and bathe in it







we have been notified that we are leaving here
 x
Entry.18:
Since coming back to the horses things are fairly dulldrill is the order of the day. Rumours are rife concerning our departure from here. it is very hard to tell when we will go

Second diary since leaving home
Entry.21:
Route march. Maadi Heloumi. 2 days am exempt Sick

a concert is to be held at tonight
Entry.23:
Maadiusual Routine

Monday 21 Muad

Colonel Onslow announced at lunch time today that the
Entry.24: Brigade of Light horse are leaving here as following the
Entry.27: - destination unknown - the news was received by the men as expected with enthusiasm. this time I think the horse are going with us this trip
Entry.28: it is not altogether taken for granted by a few that we are going awayofficers
Entry.29:
the 5th light horse left here to day

this week has been one of expectation for all.
Entry.30: the 6th light horse are leaving here to day. I visited Cairo to day went to the A E Bank. but received no satisfaction disappointment as theyare very frequent out tome lately
Entry.31: we are pulling tents down and packing prior to our scheduled departure this evening. we are carrying 140 pounds a man and leaving here in complete marching order. left Mead'a12 oclock tonight entrained for the canal with horses
Entry.32:
morning -
am travelling by train arrives at Ismalia 10.30 this morning. arrivedat Sarapeum on the Canal at 11 today (Satdy) are putting lines down ect

 is the big Junction on this line
Entry.33: fatigue Went swimming down at the Suez Canal which lies about 1½ from Sarapeumour present camp BBB menu for today is not muchhope for change tomorrow
Entry.34: the change has taken place have started training ect all ammo carried. Thecamp is about 1 half miles from it is Barren and sandy small dry scrub near the dessert, no Recreation up to date is Sarepeum our stay here will not be to interesting swimming parades are very you can swim from Africa to Asia there are camps all along the canal and first lines of defence is some miles over the on back roads.
Entry.35:
have commenced army Rations drill is the order of the day. they are taking us very steady on account of the heavy sandy going for the horses. our amunition recalled

month end up to date have no tidings of money or any letters from home
Entry.36:
- Wednesday 1

the 7th Reg are duty Reg today fatigue. the campnearly settle now things are in working order Swimming parade to the canal



this new camp Sarapean is something similar to Man'donly there is no town nearer than Ismailia which is about 9 miles away the line is quite close to us
Entry.37:
D troop are out this more as a screen for the main body Skirmishing to day was the worst day I have ever experienced - dust storms preventedour managing
great 
in theafternoon. it was awfull the food is very good now that there is butter.
Entry.38: usual Routine Drill. to day is similar to yesterday, dust storms and hot winds. the sand makes one nearly blind one. Ourparade went wellwithin 1mile of the Salt lakes this afternoon
Entry.39: The 7th are orderly Squad Swimming parade to the Canal ect - these swims are looked forward too
Entry.40: No Church paradeSarapeum on fatique to day. Windy and stillcloudy and inclined to be dusty. The N.Z.who are camping next to us hear they are going over the Canal camels trains
Entry.41: Sarapeam Skirmishing action butwind has droppedsomesand fliesvery bad.
Entry.42: Sarapeum fatigue. inline piquetcall 2 .1 placepulled down
Entry.43: Sarapeum the 7th are orderly Regiment Swimming Parade took horses in for a swim to dayin the canal
Entry.44: Sarapeumfatiqueand line work areoplanesare flying over our camp frequently allies troop trainsare passing our camp every day the 5th Regof L.H.are camped here over the fresh water canal.
Entry.46: Sarapean 5th Reg are on fatigue et S C. Swimming parade to canal Dust storms prevented our swimming parades - Received a big mail. Wrote to Authorities atMaltainquiring for money or tidings of it
Entry.47:
Sarapeam

Swimming parade with horses received cable from home Australia bankingshall theyremit money to me no reply
Entry.48: Sarapeam All day for Regiment.horsegetting shodmeant for supply of at 6 o'clock tonight (supply guess)
Entry.49:
Sarapeam News reached here to day thatTurkeyspeace proposals have been submitted to the allies (Egyptian mail) (through Switzerland)

ASquad are orderly squad all are of fatigue and guard
Entry.50: Sarapeam A Squad Orderly Squad Swimming parade canal. Swam over to Asia just on the Bank of the canal are to be seen numbers of gravestheyaretheTurkswhoattacked last year a platoonof them.
Entry.51: Sarapeum. Arepacking for a nights andleaving camp at 5oclock this evening marching under orders. night out postdutyare being returned at 10tomorrow morning. not too cold camping out
Entry.52: Arrived home from Bivouack at 11.30 to day.Rosterfor remainder of day. Sarapeum.
Entry.53: Sarapeum Weorderly squad to day. am onfatigue very dusty and windy dust storms and everything that makes one uncomfortable . Rained this night in Egypt
Entry.54: Sarapeam. The prince of wales who is now stationed at Jsmaila on the english staff was here today to review our Brigade we had a march past. he seems to be young.
Entry.55: Serapeam. A squad orderly no mounted fatigues am on supply fatigues. Rumours are afloat concerning our departure from here sportly it is still early went swimming to the canal.
Entry.56:
Sarapeam as usual fatigue engineers road making.

Rumours are rife concerning our departure from here our next move is to the east at now occupied by the turks.
Entry.57: Sarapeam. Parade are swimmingly but out on fatigues that order of the day for some days our expectation at
Entry.58: Sarapeam. Mounted parade this morning and and delivering of messages to O.C. and . very hot for horses
Entry.59: Sarapeam. supply fatigue orderly squad swimming parade. Pay day
Entry.61: Sarapeam. Morning mounted parade. tonight. the weather is at present. left camp at 4 o'clock will have tea in the desert home from post
Entry.62: Sarapeam 7 o'clock are going back to camp morning clearing up. afternoon swimming parade.
Entry.63: Sarapeam fagigues morning swimming parade afternoon swim horse along the canal.
Entry.64: Sarapeam. Today they have made new arrangements for us. We take the horses over to the canal where they can get shade. The trees are all along the canal. (there are no sheds for the horses at camp) it is a great change.
Entry.65: Sarapeam. Ditto yesterday am trying piquet tonight.
Entry.66: Sarapeam. The 7th Duty Reg. I am at fatigue on the canal. at the AnzacDivisional H.Q. the Div H.Q. is a mounted division composing of Australian L.H. and together with army and other units.
Entry.67: Sarapeam. Went church this morning. Swimming parade afternoon. Rumours rife are training today.
Entry.68: Sarapeam. were at the canal today and were recalled to pack up. we're departing from here. destination unknown are luggage too of supply . they are taking all the camp with us.
Entry.69: Ismalia. Left Sarapeam today at 12 o'clock arriving at Ismalia at 5.30 The horses took their journey well.
Entry.70:
Dessert. Left Ismalia when the camped this morning at 6 o'clock for horses. arrived at our new camp. Saretiuh. the camp is different from Sarapeam.

sheds are here. the was shot at last night. Salhia. Camels transported other things for us.
Entry.71: Salhia. Am settled in our messy champ. it is a great improvement to our last camp plenty of good water both for our horses and ourselves. this place is 30 minutes from Sarapeam.
Entry.72: Am piquet to river. Salhia. Fatigue
Entry.76: Salhia. As usual. horse picquet tonight.
Entry.77:
Salha Usual routine

the most terrible dust storm I have ever seen sprungup here tonight.
Entry.78:
-Salhia
The dust storm still continues tents blown down this last couple of days the food has been very scarce not enoughto eathad no pay for three weeks.
Entry.79:
- Salhia
When exercising horses this morning we had the heaviest downpour of rain I ever experienced whileI have been in Egypt. we are not getting sufficient food here our horses are also very short we have
Entry.80:
Salhia
General inspected the camp today pay day
Entry.81:
Salhia
Fatigue swimming rumours we are leaving this camp shortly.
Entry.85:
Salhia
Am on leave for Cairo
Entry.86:
- Cairo
Left Brg at and my own papers was recalled to camp at 4 o'clock this afternoon.
Entry.87:
Salhia
Left Cairo 6.30 Sat afteroon at camp everything packed away for departure outpostat
Entry.88: arrived 3 o'clock this morning some of the 5th brg horses have been in action 4 o'clock arrived at the rail head very little water for horses (all training) enemy not in sight yet am camping at the rail head. support duty tonight pass word (Ryrlo)
Entry.90: o'clock am leaving camp 7.30 arriving at desserted camp (belonging to Yeomanrywho were captured by the turks couple of days ago) (Des Camp) (12 o'clock) another camp everything up to date the men we passed were the victims) are taking possession of camp) captured Sunday 23
Entry.91:
No 2 camp
Password (new Zealand. my mateand I went out to bring in 2 seen a couple of from our supports and old man a a stray turk also has been seen, water supply has improved wounded turks and brought in this morning.

the life is not varying (very regular)
Entry.92:
No. 2 Des Camp
At 5.30 this morning my unitout on patrol out post duty tonight pass word (Ryrie)
Entry.93:
No. 2 Des camp
A day of heat. this morning an aeroplane scare caused us to stand to our we did not sight the 

password
Entry.94:
No. 2 Des camp
Stand to armsthis morning to despatched out post at 11 today outpost (kill (110)

Pass word
Entry.95:
No. 2 camp
general morning) at 3 o'clock we are leaving camp the 3 Reg the aeroplane bringing in a message to the effect that at Ben el Arisha party of turks are camped wewere goingto attack.
Entry.96:
(Oghratina)
We travelled by easy stages after leaving camp yesterday first stop el Katia2 hours rest) Og'hratina) were out post that night 4 o'clock to turkish camp some 12 miles distant (Ber'el Abd) turk too quick for horse destroying camp. Result of expedition 1 prisoner body of menthat rode back to camp.
Entry.97:
No. 2 Camp
A day of what the militarycall Rest an article on detail to the waterincurring the above)
Entry.98:
No. 2 camp Romani
Fatigue this morning out at the digging canal to flood the surrounding making it impossiblefor the enemy. Had a fine swim today first since leaving Sarapeam(out post duty tonight.

Received cable from Vince informs me on the 24 of march five pound were sent to me in care to Egyptian bank. Romani No. 2 Romani
Entry.99: Early this morning 4 o'clock one of our brought the news that the turnk were advancingin headquarters. Rest day.
Entry.100:
No. 2 Romani
Am patrol this morning are taking horses (remounts) to the 5th they are meeting enemyat Bir el (stable piquet tonight.
Entry.101:
No 2 camp Romani
Nothing doing ordinaryfatigues support tonight, pass word portsmouth
Entry.102:
No. 2 Camp
Fatigues in general are already much the hotest day I have ever experienced.
Entry.103:
No. 2 camp
Fatigue in general very hot outpost tonight. still very hot day stabling 5th 6th and N Z horses gone to meet the turks who are in the password (Glophil)
Entry.104:
No. 2 camp
Usual routine night off. very hot winds making this in general very uncomfortable.
Entry.105:
No. 2 Des camp
Usual Routine. Hot stints continues

They are still bringing in men with sun stroke the camels are in great demand.
Entry.106:
No. 2 camp
Left camp at 2 o'clock this morning arrived at Katina at 5.30 had breakfast left again at 4.30 2 hours outpost horse piquet tonight.
Entry.107:
No. 2 camp
Stabling of horses under the palms
Entry.108:
No. 2 camp
Swimming etc. the railway only 1 miles from here. the are portions all around our camp
Entry.109:
No 2 camp
are going to Bir el Abd tomorrow
Entry.110:
No. 2 camp
left here at 6.30 for Bir el Abd arrived at Katia camping there for the day. 7 o'clock am moving for Bir el Abd have order to
Entry.111:
Bir el Abd
1 mile 4 o'clock moving no signs of enemy 5.30 our sighted an enemy on gave chase caught 1 prisoner main body of turks some miles away. 7.30 are returning to camp old turkishcamp we arrive at camp at 5.30.
Entry.112:
No. 2 camp
Usual fatigue

Thursday 25 No 2 camp
am jumping fatigue the 6th Reg left here for Hill 70

Friday 26 No 2 camp
The 7th are leaving tomorrow at 3 in the morning for Hill 70 the
Entry.113: arrived here today. Am piquet tonight paid£2.0.0 passed the
Entry.114: which the turks attacked prior to our arrival here.
Entry.115:
Hill 70
Arrived at H 70 at old camp 8 miles from Katina
Entry.116:
Hill 70
March parade am in main camp
Entry.117:
Hill 70
Swimming parade all day sheds are to be built here for the horses.
Entry.118:
Hill 70
Are building sheds for horses and are the scotch horse infantry are also here.
Entry.120:
Hill 70
(6 Romani) The 6th Brigade of light who relieved usat Romani had a resting taube bombed the camp killing wounding others. The taubeturned the machine gun on the killing 40 also
Entry.124:
Hill 70
As per usual

News reached here today to the affect that a battle took place in the North Sea, the English losing 14 ships including the Q. Mary together with 13 others. The German losses were 15 ships including 3 battle cruises. No further particulars to hand.
Entry.125:
Hill 70
Rumours reach here today that LordKitchener was drowned it has since been comfirmed here his destination was Russhia the destroyer was the Hampshire. G. Robertson has taken command.
Entry.129:
Hill 70
Usual routine. Rumours says Bagdadis fallen. Not official
Entry.130:
Hill 70
An enemy Taubeflew over the camp this evening. It caused quite a sensation. he fired from a machine gun doing no damage a second scare also occurred but it turned to be one of our own.
Entry.138:
Hill 70
Brigadier left here for England to explaining the reason
Entry.141:
Hill 70
1 hr Brg inspected by the acting Brigadier C. Aylston this morning
Entry.142:
Hill 70
As usual Preparation for leaving
Entry.146:
Bir etMaler
As usual horse picquet

Wednesday 28 Bir et Maler
Witnessed a fight between an enemy aeroplane and one of ours they both used their machine guns they soon werelost sight of.
Entry.148:
Bir et Maler
left here for Bir el Abd arrived at
Entry.149:
Bir et Maler
as usual am leaving Katia
Entry.154:
7 

 of turkish camp 10 miles from Bir el Abd sighted 40turks but only kills 1 wounded 1 and 1 prisoner one 

Thursday 6
Entry.156:
el Neliah
left here 3 o'clock this morning for Bir el Abd arrived at Katia horses went on to Oghratina resting till 7 started for Bir el Abd continue on
Entry.164:
Biret Maler
Standing to arms cut out
Entry.167:
Biret Maler
am leaving camp 3 o'clock (Katia) aeroplane news 4000turksat Bir el Abd Ramani and at Katina that night enemy not sighted
Entry.168:
Katia
am outpost firing commenced

The 2nd Brigadeare demonstratingto draw fire partially successfully 2 turkish prisoners told us that was the turks object was to Romani

Friday 21Biret Maler
Arrived in camp 1 o'clock this morning. the turk are going to attack tonight prisoners saddles on horses.

Saturday 22Biret Maler
as the turks are in possession of Oghratina the Reg are out on reconniscence work constantly
Entry.169:
These four days are busy ones for the Reg casualities are few I have not been out lately as my horse is ill the turks are giving the numbers ones and twos

July 1916

we can only go 4 miles from Katia now enemy is in posession of the east. the well at Katia is still in our charge.
Entry.170:
Biret Maler
another stunt the taube pay us a but so far have dropped nobombs.

Friday 14 Biret Maler
Am not goingout on stunts horses sick. skirmishing is still the order ofthe day. turks still active.
Entry.172:
Et Maler
Tom Mitchell was shot through stomach today whilst out in the scrub . was taken into Kantara
Entry.173:
Et Maler
Tom died is buried in the cemetary at Kantara

Small movement by our Brigade
Entry.174: on our line few turks dead our casualties light turks done up
Entry.176:
in morning returned fromlisteningpost.2nd Brigade are returning wounded are coming in am going to look for my lot. found them.

Thursday 3EtMaler
The turks attack our camp another stunt am listening post tonight at 12 o'clock hear firing commencing all along the surrounding ridge (the turks havingmade their long delayed attack at 3 o'clock we left this part to depart to the outpost then away.
Entry.177: patrolled a couple of miles out the attack by this time had begun in earnest. I looked for my lot but could not find them I rode along the line and picked them up at about 8 o'clock and about a mile our casualities were light.
Entry.178: Advance this morning light casualities took prisoners am following them down have them back to Katia more captives also a red cross (our) outpost (10 o'clock) 11 o'clock am working around () Katia are 6 o'clockare going to charge
Entry.179:
We retired from Katia at 7 o'clock. rear guard all in.

Sunday 6 - EtMaler
Are back in camp for a spell it is quite safe again. their snipers played up our left in camp
Entry.180:
EtMaler
Are goingout tonight the and up to date
Entry.182:
Oghratina
Escorted a camel train out to Oghratina from Romani again the turks are
Entry.185:
Et Maler
Things are very quite at Bir et Abd the turk appears to be with at any slight sorry to say we are
Entry.186:
Et Maler
The Reg has came back no news we are well supplied with info now.
Entry.187:
Et Maler
camp are again is giving
Entry.188:
Speach by General congratulating us on our success.

Wednesday 16 Et Maler
Entry.189: things in camp have settled down to normal. the turk do not pay us many visits.
Entry.191:
Et Maler
are leaving camp to scout the country between Oghratina and Katia
Entry.192:
Katia
Have found nothing of the the English infantry have all returned to Romani
Entry.196: As usual the attackwas one that time the turks evidently had enough
Entry.199:
26

 Et Maler still resting have had no news from for some time
Entry.202:
Et Maler
Our info brought a german tank at Oghratina
Entry.205:
Friday Et Maler
am sick in
Entry.206:
field hospital
Sick bombed port said today doing little damage

Saturday 2 Rail head
am leaving for Kantina
Entry.207:
Kantina
Am in 26th casualty clearing station
Entry.208:
26 casuality clearing station
Am feeling done up our aeroplane bombarded a turkish camp in counter op their attacks on port said
Entry.209:
Cas. clearing station
am leaving by the for P. Said
Entry.211:
Gen P Said
am convalesnt am not feeling too good. this hospital had at one time been a shipbuilding yard.
Entry.212:
this hospital was originally built for a dock yards as it is well nigh completion and seems that purpose it is now used for.

Thursday 7 
All well

Friday 8 31st General P. Said
all well
Entry.216:
31 General P Said
am marked down for Cario
Entry.219:
Hospital train
am leaving P. Said 31 Gen for Cairo
Entry.220:
at G. H.
arrived in Cairo Met Dr. am not feeling too good
Entry.221:
Mostashfa Alexandria
am convalescent a modest place like palace of the
Entry.229:
Mostashfa details
am attached to the 2nd Brg details. It does not seem the best of places all men are
Entry.240: the tip at this camp Reg are in at Hill 70
Entry.252:
Friday 20
Saturday 21

 as usual at Mostashfa
Entry.257:
November. 1916

November. 1916

Thursday 9
Received letter from
Entry.258:
Mostashfa
the Germans bombed Cairo today few casualties
Entry.264:
22

 Mostashfa things are just usual here
